ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Quantum Information basics (what is a qubit, what are the Pauli matrices, logical gates, constructing circuits, foundational quantum algorithms, a lot of good linear algebra).
Got a deeper understanding of quantum computing and developed my knowledge of probabilities.
The fundamentals of Quantum computing, including qubits, entanglement, phase kickback, and quantum algorithms

In my opinion there are three pillars to this course (in chronological order):
1. Information is physical, therefore the foundations of computer science are grounded in physics.
2. Randomness is inherent in the behavior of quantum systems. This is capable of providing a computational advantage in the strangest ways imaginable.
3. Once this "randomness" is understood, we may begin to understand quantum algorithms and their cleverness. There are many more discoveries to be made!

This course explored many topics in basic information theory, the behavior of quantum information systems, basic quantum hardware, and algorithms that can run on a quantum computer. Homework exercises built our familiarity with concepts like superposition, entanglement, and randomness in quantum systems.
I learned the fundamentals of quantum information.
Quantum Computing, Quantum Algorithms
Really cool intro to quantum computing. One of the better interdisciplinary physics courses here
How entanglement allows you to compute some things in quantum computers faster than in classical computers.
Quantum physics and computation, use of Qiskit, some basic quantum algorithms
I learned about introductory concepts and techniques in the field of quantum computing.
How quantum works (qubits, information encoding/passing/communication, etc)
This course is an introduction to quantum computing algorithms.

I learned a TON of linear algebra as it relates to quantum states in the first half of the course. The second half was mostly about various applications of quantum principles for famous quantum algorithms. We also learned how to construct quantum circuits for IBM virtual machines.
Basic principles and algorithms in Quantum Information Science. How to conduct an independent final research project for a Physics class.

I learned how information theory and quantum theory overlap, a lot of the linear algebra that is invested into quantum information, and a lot of the applications of quantum theory to our lives today and tomorrow. I was able to gain a much better intuition of quantum states, and why the properties of quantum states make it possible for it to compute problems more efficiently than classic computers. I also learned to use the IBM Composer to build quantum circuits, and how to use these resources moving forward.

An amazing overview of quantum information studies and computing made intuitive! We learned about classical information, computation and gates, operations on and measurements of qubits, multiqubit systems and entanglement, quantum algorithms, and quantum error correction.
I learned about the laws of quantum information and their applications to the challenge of quantum computation.
Lots of theory, linear algebra
Knowledge of quantum computing fundamentals and algorithms
A basic introduction to quantum computing that covers important quantum gates and algorithms.
A better understanding or how quantum algorithms work, and what the future May hold in this exciting field. Also more about quantum time complexity

Classical information theory, a model of classical computation using logical gates, the mathematical foundation for the analysis of quantum states and measurements, quantum dense coding and teleportation, the no-cloning theorem, various quantum algorithms (Deutsch, Deutsch-Jouza, Simon's, Quantum Fourier Transform, Amplification and Grover Search), and quantum error correction
Quantum Information
The course was extremely interesting, one of my favourite classes at yale content wise
Topics in quantum information and quantum computation, using the IBM quantum composer to run simulations, quantum algorithms.

I learned about quantum algorithms and quantum circuits, and on a very theoretical level how they work. Depending on your background coming into this class you will get something very different out of it (like someone more physics-oriented will get exposure to probability theory, linear algebra, and some randomized algorithms).

Foundations of quantum mechanics of spin-1/2 systems, thorough introduction to quantum information and computing theory including single and multi qubit states, operations and gates, entanglement and basic quantum algorithms. Insight into the current state of quantum computing and its potential applications to problems intractable to classical computers. Basic introduction to quantum circuit design tools.
Learned the basics of quantum computing from the ground level up.
a thorough overview of quantum information
basic concepts of quantum computers, algorithms, linear algebra
I learned about the theory of quantum computation, from models of information and quantum bits up to practical algorithms. Assignments emphasized mathematical problem-solving in applied contexts.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I love that there are weekly Psets to keep me on track with the material. The Psets also directly test for understanding, and I believe are just right in difficulty to make sure we grasp the basics firmly instead of flailing around in confusion. Prof Girvin is also such a wonderful teacher. His love for the subject is truly infectious. I took this class just to fulfill distributional requirements, but Prof Girvin's course (all of it) actually makes me seriously consider taking the field into consideration in my future prospects! The TAs are also the most patient and kindest life savers in the class. No weaknesses!

Excellent professor! Excellent TAs and wonderful peer tutors! The content is also great! The one thing I would change is that the problem sets were sometimes much harder/ complicated, so I would appreciate if more of that material was covered on the lectures.

Strengths: Good lectures and notes
Weaknesses: Teaching staff provided less assistance than expected.

Overall, the course was really well taught. As with every class this year, it would have benefited from being in person, where it is easier to discuss and ask questions. The course notes were excellent, and there were prewritten ones posted with the live notes so that students could prepare before lecture, and then review the same material after lecture. The lectures were very interesting, and didn't move too fast or slow.
I thought it was a very good, and especially for its first year being taught it was very well done.

Strengths: Grading distribution (25% for each component) is pretty balanced.
Weaknesses:
1. Prof. Girvin would either sprint through his already written notes, so we didn't have time to copy them, or he would write them (and talk) slowly. I watched lectures at 1.5x or 1.75x.
2. By the end of the course, I don't know precisely what quantum computing is. The first half of the course barely touched on it, and I wish I had waited for the CS department to offer this course.
3. Midterm had 4 short questions. One silly mistake and you're sitting at a B.

Strengths - Prof Girvin explains the concepts very well, clear notes, makes you excited about quantum physics
Weakness - The psets are a bit uneven in difficulty

The course was interesting, but was definitely geared toward CS majors over Physics majors. The first half of the course was entirely Quantum mechanics that would have been covered in any other Quantum class.

Strengths: Enjoyed the professor's lectures, he was very knowledgable and entertaining.

Weaknesses: Because it was designed for a wide array of students, the pace moved really slow for those of us already familiar with the course material. It would be nice if there was a more fast paced version of the course.

Strength: Girvin is an absolute beast who is an actual pioneer in the field; fast grading and solid psets overall
Weakness: weekly psets became somewhat annoying (especially the ibm simulations)

The material in this course is interesting, and Professor Girvin taught it well. His course notes (which are essentially a short textbook!) are very, very well done. It would have also been nice to see some more of the hardware side. Despite being extensive, the support structure for this course (TAs, peer tutors) were lacking; I gave up going to their sessions as they were never helpful.

Professor Givin taught this course technically very well. I also took PHYS 260/261 with him, and that was an absolute joy. This course was okay. His energy and enthusiasm do not carry quite as well on Zoom, but that is not his fault as Zoom is a dumpster fire that deserves do be thrown into a woodchipper covered in fire ants.

Strengths: Interesting lectures, constructing quantum circuits was fun (like puzzles)
Weaknesses: Often difficult psets, a final paper in a physics class along with a final

Prof. Girvin knows his stuff, and for that reason the class was a joy to take. 

I wish we had had more opportunities to work with the IBM Quantum Composer on our problem sets. 

A version of this class with Physics 439/440/441 as a prerequisite would be amazing for students who already have a background in Quantum Mechanics/the vector space formalism, because a lot of the first half of the class was devoted to review of those concepts. But I also understand the value of having a class accessible to Computer Science majors or Physics majors who haven't taken QM yet. That said, from my conversations with fellow students it seems like the survey of QM was too fast for students outside the Physics major to really get it, but slow enough that students with QM experience didn't really feel challenged.

I think the course was very well structured at a high level, starting with basic information theory, and moving on to the basics of quantum information. Lectures followed the course notes mostly, and were easy to follow. Professor Girvin was clear in his explanations of many quantum concepts, and I though the pace of course was just slow enough to properly gain some intuition for a lot of the concepts, like entanglement and phase kickback. The course was a bit weaker near the end, when we were exploring different quantum algorithms. Organization was bit more lacking, although understandably so, and lectures covered high-level concepts rather than details.

This class gives you a solid understanding of quantum computing and inspires you to be the one to press our progress forward. The content is presented at a good pace and curiosity is encouraged. PSETs get to the essentials and provide good practice; the tests are also very fair. This was easily one of my favorite classes! Professor Girvin is absolutely amazing! He is incredibly passionate, helpful, and cares about the learning of his students. It serves as an amazing introduction to the subject. The course notes and copious provided resources were exceedingly useful. It is a wonderful class and there are not any weaknesses.
Homework assignments and the final project were clear, but it was sometimes difficult to follow with the textbook, which I found more useful than the lectures.

The strength of this course was the instructor's breadth of experience in the field and the fascinating material. This course was very multidisciplinary and encompassed a broad range of subjects, and the course benefited greatly from this diversity. I think the course could be improved by focyusing more on using quantum simulators and quantum API's, as these are the format in which quantum computation is nowadays more readily applicable.
Strength: nice professor, Weakness: Hard psets that didn't align with lectures
Fantastic course, super interesting. A bit disorganized but that can be explained by this being the first year it was taught. I'm certain it will only improve over time.

Strengths: this course covers a basic introduction to quantum computing without requiring any prerequisite knowledge in physics (just some linear algebra), making this course super accessible to students from a wide variety of backgrounds. Furthermore, the course was also rather low workload, with short but informative psets, allowing you to spend some time synthesizing the weirdness of quantum computing instead. Weaknesses: Prof Girvin lectures pretty slowly, so his lectures can get dull at points (especially if you don't have a 2x button to speed him up).
Really solid! As someone who took 261, the course def started slow for me, but I really enjoyed building upon my previous knowledge. I also loved the course notes!!!

Strengths: covers a wide variety of topics at a depth that is accessible to students from a range of majors. Weakness: I felt like the first half of the course was a bit slow. Either speeding up the first half or going more in-depth into the mathematical theory could improve the first half.
Professor Girvin is obviously a world-class expert in the field, and also a really nice/helpful person. However, the course was a bit disorganized, which made it harder than it should have been
The grading and feedback could be improved. It felt very harsh at times with little to no indication as to why

Professor Girvin's notes are a huge strength. They are very thorough and explain the material well. I think one weakness that just came from this being the first time was that the course moved a bit slow in the beginning, which led to us not getting to all the planned material.

The course gives a good overview of central concepts in quantum information and touches on some of the more advanced topics in the later part of the course. The course notes are comprehensive and very helpful.

Strengths: Very interesting course content, fair and manageable workload, Prof. Girvin is the master of his field, TAs/staff are very good with office hours and give great feedback on all assignments

Weaknesses: Expectations for the project were extremely unclear. I definitely could've done better with more guidance in that regard.

This course explains clearly and in detail all concepts required to understand state-of-the-art quantum computing research, in an order that clearly builds upon previous topics. It also lays a good foundation for the linear algebra and probability knowledge required to analyze quantum systems. The algorithms discussed in class give a good idea of where the quantum advantage lies. The independent project was a great opportunity for students to pursue their own interests in this broad and exciting field. However, it would have been helpful to know the grading criteria and expectations for the project more clearly in advance. It would have also been very interesting to hear more about real quantum algorithms instead of only proof-of-concept ones, as well as about quantum hardware.

The material of the course was very interesting and engaging, and Professor Girvin does a great time teaching the material. My only critique is sometimes the psets felt like busy work that was largely unrelated to the content from lectures.
more example problems would have been much more helpful

Prof. Girvin's creation of a curriculum accessible to students with little background in the area, including his textbook-like course notes, was this course's major strength. His detailed answers to questions both in lectures and in office hours were also very helpful. I would have like to have learned more about the physical implementation of quantum devices, though I understand that this might not have been possible with the course's limited prerequisites.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was great that the course had so much support from TAs and tutors!
Mostly good.

Office hours were very helpful, and there were lots of time slots available due to the flexibility of being able to hold zoom office hours whenever. Professor Girvin stressed that we could raise our hands and interrupt at any time, which made asking questions during class much more approachable and improved engagement.
I thought it was the best it couldve been during the pandemic.

The use of remote quantum computing via Qiskit was very effective, and not at all impacted by the remote semester. Lectures were recorded. Prof Girvin included a final project for this course, which gave us the freedom to explore further in a quantum computing topic of interest while reducing the stress of exams.
not much, pretty standard covid course.
The recorded lectures provided much the same experience as in-person lectures.

I thought the live virtual lectures, and frequent study sessions/office hours were very useful. Perhaps the textbook could have been more fleshed out near the end of the course and notation could have been clearer at times, but overall, the course did well to adapt to COVID-19.

Lecture recordings were exceedingly useful, especially with time zone differences. I also appreciated how rapidly course notes would be uploaded to Canvas. The class had a strong community with many of my friends being made to discuss PSETs.

The practices in this course were largely sucessful in the online format. The office hours were helpful and accessible, the comments on problem sets improved my understanding, and the lecture notes were easy to review and process.
Holding frequent office hours? Leaving space for questions during lecture
Prof. Girvin was great in slowing down his lectures to deal with the increased difficulty of being present on Zoom meetings for so long. He was also receptive to feedback during the course as well.
the lectures were good

The format of the course was a fairly standard lecture, which didn't need to change much for Zoom. Prof. Girvin gave good answers to live student questions even in the virtual format, and was quite accessible and helpful at office hours. The timed open-note exams worked well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! Take any class with Prof Girvin. You will learn so much.
Yes! Excellent course, especially if Professor Girvin is teaching it!
This is such a cool topic and I would definitely recommend it to anyone with an interest in quantum computing, I met great people and learned so many cool things through this class
Take it only if you have taken quantum physics.

If you have an interest in quantum computing, definitely. However, the concepts were not as straightforward as it sounded, and a lot of math background is needed that stated in order to get a full grasp of the material.
I definitely would - it's pretty accessible for a beginner and very interesting!

I would recommend this class to anyone interested in quantum computing. There was an excellent mix of physicists, engineers, mathematicians, and non STEM people taking the course, and the course material spanned all of those areas. The material is not easy, but you come away from the class feeling like you've learned a lot about a topic that is cutting edge in the world of physics.
Definitely, it gives you a lot of insight to a fascinating and new field!
Absolutely!!
Yes if you are interested in physics and computer/information science and their overlap
I'd probably recommend them to wait for the CS department to offer a quantum computation class.
Yes, great introduction to quantum computers and what they can do, lets you better appreciate the "hype" from a Physics/CS/EE perspective.
Yes, if they are interested in exploring the idea.

Yes, especially to CS or math majors who havent taken a physics class. Its super interesting material that you wont learn in other departments and Girvin makes it really accessible to people who know basic math (i.e linear algebra). Not an insane amount of work and not super hard material, but also not easy material and it takes a while to grasp how quantum bits actually work.

This is an interesting and unique course on quantum computing that is taught very well. I would definitely recommend taking this course if one has not taken PHYS 261 with Girvin. If one has, then I might steer clear as this course is probably about 75% overlap, even though professor Girvin will assure you that you will learn new material.

This class is great as long as you manage your expectations correctly. A lot of CS students took it thinking it wouldn't be super difficult, especially as there are no prerequisites. However, you should be very comfortable with lots of linear algebra, and some background in quantum mechanics would have been helpful. This definitely isn't a science gut, but it is very interesting. Prof Girvin is amazing, and lectures were always well taught. Just be prepared to struggle with the psets for a while each week.

Definitely. This class taught me so much about the up and coming field of quantum information, and made it clear why a second quantum revolution is currently underway. It gave context to an exciting time, and set us up with the mathematical basics behind the quantum processes. It was also detailed enough for students to gain intuition about some difficult quantum concepts, and learn how to apply it independently in our final project. I learned a lot in the course, thanks to the great organization, well-framed problem sets, and clear feedback.

Definitely, you must take this!! Professor Girvin is exceptional, and although very humble, is an expert on the subject. You truly learn so much in this class and the content is super interesting. The intuitive explanations of qubits and laying down of the fundamental rules we have to work with make the subject approachable from all backgrounds (the appendices in the course notes can catch you up on any math you might not have seen). The class then becomes incredibly illuminating and inspiring; there is a sense that you are incredibly lucky to be there. I have had a blast. Please take this class!
Yes, if they are interested in learning about quantum computing and quantum mechanics through the lens of quantum information.

I would defentily recommend this course! Professor Michel Devoret gave a talk in which he said that the study of quantum information is not simply quantum computing, but and investigation of one of the fundamental behaviors of the universe. I felt that this class did justice to the amazing phenomenon of quantum mechanics and investigated one of its most surprising applications.
No
Certainly, as long as they were vaguely interested in quantum computing.

If you're interested in learning more about one of the biggest buzzwords in science right now, take it. It's super accessible to anyone into STEM, and only assumes a basic knowledge of linear algebra (that is itself reviewed in the first few classes). It's a low work, high reward course and is super easy to get an A in - there's literally nothing to hesitate about.
Yes! A fun course and pretty gentle I troduction to quantum information. Useful for different majors and compatible with different backgrounds.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in quantum computation. Quantum computation is one of the hottest (and personally, one of the most interesting) topics right now, and it is definitely helpful to have some background so that you can follow along with some of the progress that is being made.
Probably
Yes, if it becomes a bit more structured.

If you took Phys 261 with Girvin, a lot of this will seem like review. However the second half of the class once we got to algorithms was really interesting. I think in the future that will be more of the class, so yeah I'd recommend this course. Also, Girvin is great and extremely knowledgeable about this stuff.
Yes if you are interested in quantum information! This course does not require prior knowledge in quantum mechanics and is accessible to students with some linear algebra background.

Yes, I would. This course has the potential to be one of the legendary classes Yale is known for - a once niche subject now exploding in relevance taught by the GOAT in his field (Girvin) - but I'd say at the moment the course is good and not quite great. There are definitely still a few kinks to work out, which is totally understandable since this is the first time 345 has been offered (for example, Prof. Girvin revised his course notes, sometimes even retroactively, as the class went on), but quantum computing is such a cool subject that the class was still extremely worth taking. Since it's an intro class with very few prerequisites, people came into the semester with vastly different backgrounds and got vastly different stuff out of it because of that. For example, I took this class after taking all the probability, CS, and linear algebra that 345 assumed but not any of the quantum mechanics (though I did have classical mechanics from 260). The quantum stuff we covered all flew entirely over my head so it really felt like a randomized algorithms class. But it was possible to do all the work without conceptually grasping all the physics, so I still did well despite feeling kinda lost in the lectures. I imagine the flip side is true as well: you can do well in the course with lots of quantum background and learning the more mathy stuff on the fly. But it does mean that people are confused about very different things in office hours so I sometimes started freaking out when someone asked a question seemingly unrelated to anything I had been thinking about. The actual work you have to do is heavily computational and there isn't much of it, so it really made a perfect science credit for me, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone else taking math/stats/CS looking for a relevant and relatively chill Sc class. (If his plans haven't changed, Prof. Girvin will be on leave next spring but plans to offer 345 again in the 2022-23 school year.)
I would recommend this course as a great introduction to an exciting and rapidly developing field for any students interested in physics or computer science.
Absolutely! Great science credit for math/econ/cs majors that is interesting and engaging, while being neither too easy nor too hard.
Yes, if you are interested in the applications of quantum mechanics then definitely take this course

Yes, this class was a good introduction to quantum information. I'm a CS major and the class was pretty accessible since there's no physics involved. But at the same time you have to take some of the concepts for granted since we don't go into the physics of things. The first half of the class was mainly linear algebra/Dirac notation, but towards the end we learned some interesting algorithms.

Yes, especially to a mathematically-inclined computer science student who is interested in learning about quantum computing at an idealized theoretical level. The course material was carefully prepared to be understandable to students with little background in the area, and built from the very basics up to practical quantum algorithms, though this meant that the physical realities of implementation were heavily de-emphasized. Some experience with algebraic problem-solving, such as an introductory physics course, is very helpful as preparation.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recordings were also available for the lectures.
Latex and handwritten notes on Canvas
Lecture was live, and were recorded for students to view on their own time.
Plus some assignments in IBM Qiskit
na
I learned primarily by watching live lectures, attending office hours, and studying the textbook.
Lectures were also recorded for convenience and lectures notes were quickly processed and uploaded to Canvas.
Lectures were also recorded.
Office hours and problem sets
N/A
Recorder lecture
Also live virtual office hours
Recorded lectures and virtual office hours were also available.
Office Hours
I was live virtual lecture but I watched recorded afterwards
I watched half of the lectures recorded after the fact (since I took two classes with overlapping times)
none
